Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Campus Design: Midtown WAN Redesign for GIS and CIS Science Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
As HACC, Central Pennsylvania's Community College, and its computing and network infrastructure continue to mature, the College needs to expand available bandwidth for its science and technology programs. The infrastructure connecting HACCÃ­s science and technology programs at two physical locations and to the Internet is limited to 100Mbps. At each of these connection points, HACC is replacing switch equipment, core routing equipment and the wide area network (WAN) connection. To support large science datasets and their flow across the network, HACC must re-architect the network infrastructure and redesign the virtual local area network (VLAN) architecture. This redesign of the VLAN architecture supports segmentation of the science and learning programs, including Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and Computer Information Systems (CIS), and allows these programs to be situated on their own 1Gbps VLAN connections with expanded science and technology classroom connectivity from 100 Mbps to 1Gbps.

As a result of this project, HACC students and faculty will have access to online educational materials in one place, accessible from anywhere, and the ability to learn remotely and use time on campus efficiently. This project supports the implementation of HACC's science and technology symposia, current and potential grant-funded projects, service and research projects and mobile learning course-content production. HACC will be better able to prepare an educated workforce for Pennsylvania's key industries, including energy, technology, manufacturing and agribusiness. This model can be a foundation for HACC's other campuses and other regional institutions to implement similar projects and programs to support STEM education.

Institution.Name: Harrisburg Area Community College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: HARRISBURG AREA COMMUNITY COLLEGE FOUNDATION, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Overview – The goals of the Midtown WAN redesign for GIS and CIS Science Research were to (1) expand the connectivity between HACC’s Midtown site and the Harrisburg Campus to facilitate data bandwidth; and (2) expand classroom connectivity from 100Mbps to 1Gbps at the Midtown classrooms to support the large data sets for GIS and the large internet downloads or CIS programs.

Goal 1 – In November 2016, HACC successfully expanded connectivity between HACC’s Midtown site (which is part of the Harrisburg Campus) from 100Mbps to 1Gbps.

Goal 2 – In June 2017, HACC expanded classroom connectivity to support large file transfers by replacing the router core equipment and network wiring switches, expanding internet connectivity from 350Mbps to 500Mbps and expanding backbone connectivity between wiring closets from 100Mbps to 20Gbps.

Project Outcomes – HACC is engaged in several science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) projects that have benefitted from both the expanded connectivity and enhanced reliability of the network as a result of this grant-funded project. For example, HACC’s GIS faculty and staff hosted a Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Day at HACC’s Midtown site on Nov. 16, 2016. GIS Day is an annual event that promotes interest in learning GIS technology and careers in the field. For more information about HACC’s GIS Day, visit http://tinyurl.com/y7ekle3x.

Computer Information Systems (CIS) faculty have also benefitted from the expanded connectivity. This advancement has allowed them to change their instructional methods and approaches within STEM courses. For example, Douglas Brown M.Ed., associate professor of computer networking technology, engineering and technology, now allows his students to download large Linux ISO images as part of the learning experience. In the past, students could not perform that task, thus negatively impacting the learning experience. Professor Brown also began to use YouTube video podcasts to provide additional on-demand instruction to his STEM students to help them complete their assigned coursework.

This project took just under two years to complete, which was longer than expected, due to delays encountered with the fiber cable installation and external influences, such as a vendor strike. However, the results of the project were evident as early as November 2016 and continued to evolve in 2017. All STEM courses taught in the Midtown location now benefit from the expanded connectivity, and HACC faculty have commented on the improved performance and network reliability. External partner, KINBER, and a contracted network engineer from Morefield Communication assisted our internal HACC network engineer to design and implement a network architecture that expanded connectivity and provided increased reliability and performance for our STEM programs located at HACC’s Midtown location.

The grant project goals and objectives were completed with less funding than expected. As a result, there is a budget surplus of $45,089.49 (21.58 percent of the total grant amount). The consultant fees, materials and supplies and travel cost less than expected, and the College did not need to provide release time for faculty participation.  

NSF Cyberinfrastructure Grant

Goal 1 – In November 2016, HACC successfully expanded connectivity between HACC?s Midtown site (which is part of the Harrisburg Campus) from 100Mbps to 1Gbps. Goal 2 – In June 2017, HACC expanded classroom connectivity to support large file transfers by replacing the router core equipment and network wiring switches, expanding internet connectivity from 350Mbps to 500Mbps and expanding backbone connectivity between wiring closets from 100Mbps to 20Gbps. GIS Day is an annual event that promotes interest in learning GIS technology and careers in the field. For more information about HACC?s GIS Day, visit http://tinyurl.com/y7ekle3x. Computer Information Systems (CIS) faculty have also benefitted from the expanded connectivity. This advancement has allowed them to change their instructional methods and approaches within STEM courses. For example, Douglas Brown M.Ed., associate professor of computer networking technology, engineering and technology, now allows his students to download large Linux ISO images as part of the learning experience. This project took just under two years to complete, which was longer than expected, due to delays encountered with the fiber cable installation and external influences, such as a vendor strike. All STEM courses taught in the Midtown location now benefit from the expanded connectivity, and HACC faculty have commented on the improved performance and network reliability.
